review_blob:
A - Floral with a noticeable sweet smell (bubblegum, as mentioned on the bottle) from the Belgian yeast.
A - Deep gold hue with an off-white head. Quite clear but for a chill haze. Looks beautiful and inviting.
T - Yeasty on the attack. The floral and sweet notes shine through as the beer pours over the tongue. Just as the bitterness arrives, the crossover from sweet to bitter creates a false (and quite subtle) tart effect on the sides of the tongue. Blast of Stone IPA bitterness arrives on the finish and sits with you for a comfortable amount of time after the gulp. Wonderfully unique!
P - Body of the beer is spot on--full enough to match it's flavor complexity, but light enough to actually be refreshing. My only complaint is that I wish the carbonation were a bit smoother on the attack. I feel the carbobite masks a lot of the flavor you should taste the second the beer hits the tongue.
O - This brewery makes so many IPAs I don't even have the time or funds to try all of them (and I spend a lot of time and money on beer). This was one of the more unique IPAs I've tasted from Stone and is a memorable and delicious twist on the classic Stone IPA. Great brew.

"Never turn your back on your beer."

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A - floral, piney, sweet, and bready
A - beautiful Amber hue with a lightly-tanned head
T - Floral on the bite. Pine flavors shine through in the middle of sip. Bitterness takes over at the back end, but doesn't overwhelm.
P - little carbobite on the front but quickly smooths out. Quite heavy, but not creamy or rich.
O - Great beer. Bittersweet (sweetbitter, rather) and Balanced.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a snifter.

A - Smells of coffee and dark fruits, particularly raisins.

A - Pours ultra dark brown and looks fully opaque black as the glass fills up. The tan head recedes very quickly to only leave a little bubbly ring where the brew meets the glass wall.

T - Taste is consistent with the aroma. Initially sweet on the attack--tastes raisiny with a tinge of coffee and booze. The creamy milk stout qualities are revealed as a mere subtle gesture at the middle of the sip. The finish cuts right through these sweet/milky aspects and hits you with that roasty coffee flavor--a little woodiness and booziness is present as well.

P - On the attack of the sip I thought the brew was going to be over carbonated, but the bite mellows out pretty quickly and let's all the flavors take precedence. The initial bite may even work in favor of the beer, helping cut down the tongue's perception of the initial sweetness so that the sweetness doesn't take over. Really liked the mouthfeel of this brew.

O - This brew didn't rock my world, but it was an interesting--perhaps even memorable--drink. All at once, this brew showcases many flavors commonly found in 3 or 4 different stout varieties. It's reminiscent of Milk (first and foremost), Coffee, American Imperial, and even Irish (particularly the sour notes found in Guinness) Stouts. Really enjoyed this brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: JAN 20, 2015
beer_name: Abita Bourbon Street Barrel Aged Imperial Stout

review_blob:
Poured from a 33cl bottle into a tulip glass.

AROMA - smells of spices and tart fruits up front. A hint of alcohol in the aroma as well.

APPEARANCE - Brew pours a deep amber hue with a smooth and fluffy beige head.

TASTE - The attack hits you with spices and plenty of fruit flavors. It's actually much sweeter than I expected based on the aromas. Not way too sweet, but a tad syrupy. The middle of the sip continues that sweetness while the spices build then leave you with an alcohol chest warming on the finish.

PALATE - has a good amount of carbonation to it, perhaps just a hair too much. But it is satisfactory. The brew remains just smooth enough that the carbonation doesn't detract from wide array flavors and rich, silky body.

OVERALL - I enjoy this beer and I'm quite glad I picked up a four pack. It has a lot of flavors packed inside and is balanced fairly well. My main deduction is that the brew's aroma made me crave more tartness in the taste, but I was given an unexpected amount of sweetness. Sweetness is a good thing (although I'm not a huge fan of very sweet foods or beers), but I felt deceived. I'll take the Tremens or Nocturnum over this any other day, but this is nevertheless a good beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a 750ml bottle into a chalice.

A - brew smells fruity, spicy, a bit malty, and boozy.

A - Pours beautifully. Very dark Amber and an appropriate level of murkiness for a Belgian. The light tan head looks silky as ever!

T - taste is fruity and boozy up front, which continues through the middle of the sip while revealing some maltiness. The finish reflects spices and a hint of pine.

P - Feels wonderful in my mouth! Beer is full-bodied with a tight carbonation. Smooth, but very bubbly.

O - Definitely a great beer. I am a very big fan of Belgian ales and this one didnt disappoint. Its true to the Belgian strong dark ale style--Big, fruity, spicy, and boozy. It doesnt push the styles boundaries by any means. But I dont think thats what the brewers at Brooklyn set out to do with this beer. So with that, I consider this beer a success!

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a snifter.

A - Smells of bourbon sweetness and alcohol up front. There is plenty of woodiness in the aroma and definitely a big malt backbone.

A - Pours like old motor oil! Super dark and opaque black with a tight, light brown head.

T - Woah! This is one of the more intense bourbon imperial stouts Ive tasted. The attack of the sip is loaded with bourbon sweetness and oakiness. The middle of the sip is where the deep maltiness makes its presence known. The bitterness starts to set in at this point as well. Upon swallowing, the brew has a big alcohol bite to it, but its a pleasant bite that cuts through all that maltiness and sweetness. Then youre left with a satisfying, bitter finish.

P - Very full and rich mouthfeel with the PERFECT carbonation level, if you ask me. Most bourbon stouts Ive tasted are enjoyably smooth, but a little too under-carbonated. This brew has a nice little "carbobite" that helps balance all the heaviness and sweetness of a barrel aged imperial stout.

O - Blown away. I will always remain loyal to my Memphis brewers, but I have seen many forgettable--good, but unremarkable--small batches and special releases get released by Wiseacre over the last year. This brew caught me by complete surprise. It is intense and very sweet, but ultra malty and balanced all at the same time. I believe this to be the brewerys finest specialty brew (if not finest brew, overall) to date. Thanks, Wiseacre!

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle bottle into a tulip glass. A - Brew pours a dark Amber with a medium-bodied off-white head. A - I smell semi-sweet cranberries and straw. T - The attack of the sip brings a small amount of tartness, but the moment I gulp is when the full puckering effect sets in. This is followed by a taste subtle cranberry sweetness that continues through the finish. Brew has plenty of cranberry flavor, but is not overwhelmingly sweet or tart. Very well-balanced and refreshing. P - Beer is well-carbonated. The opening bite of carbonation and tartness work in harmony, grabbing your attention right at the start of the sip. I do wish the beer had a bit more thickness to it. Was too light-bodied despite having a lot of flavor. O - I picked this beer up on a whim when in visited my home state of WI for Christmas (Ive been living in Memphis, TN for the last 5 years). I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed the brew. The Brewers were faithful to the true flavor of tart WI cranberries. Ive tasted too many disappointing fruit ales that were packed with sugar. This beer was well-balanced, tart, a tinge sweet, and refreshing. I definitely recommend this if you like fruit beers and especially if you like cranberries! "Never turn your back on your beer."Earlier Rating: 1/13/2015 Total Score: 3.5Poured from a 12oz bottle bottle into a tulip glass. A - Brew pours a dark Amber with a medium-bodied off-white head. A - I smell semi-sweet cranberries and straw. T - The attack of the sip brings a small amount of tartness, but the moment I gulp is when the full puckering effect sets in. This is followed by a taste subtle cranberry sweetness that continues through the finish. Brew has plenty of cranberry flavor, but is not overwhelmingly sweet or tart. Very well-balanced and refreshing. P - Beer is well-carbonated. The opening bite of carbonation and tartness work in harmony, grabbing your attention right at the start of the sip. I do wish the beer had a bit more thickness to it. Was too light-bodied despite having a lot of flavor. O - I picked this beer up on a whim when in visited my home state of WI for Christmas (Ive been living in Memphis, TN for the last 5 years). I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed the brew. The Brewers were faithful to the true flavor of tart WI cranberries. Ive tasted too many disappointing fruit ales that were packed with sugar. This beer was well-balanced, tart, a tinge sweet, and refreshing. I definitely recommend this if you like fruit beers and especially if you like cranberries!

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a snifter glass. Lots of pumpkin aroma present just when cracking the beer. Brew pours a hazy, dark copper with a creamy, off-white head. Looks very inviting! Most notable flavors are ginger and pumpkin. The ginger overwhelms the pumpkin a little more than I would have liked, but nonetheless is very tasty. Palate is a bit rich, but is still very drinkable. Has a tingle of carbonation and spice at the front end and sweet pumpkin juice at the finish. This brew didnt blow my mind, but is still a very delicious and drinkable brew.

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a snifter glass. Pours an opaque ultra dark brown--essentially black--with absolutely no head. I even tried swirling the bottle while pouring to get it to kick up a little foam, and nothing. As the beer settled in the glass I could see some bubbles rise along the glass wall. Aroma is strong of bourbon with some malt roastiness. Taste is bourbon at the front, a slightly sour coffee and chocolate in the middle, and a little bitter bite at the finish. Brew is smooth on the tongue, but just too under-carbonated for my preference. Overall, I felt this was a good, although not very impressive bourbon-aged imperial stout. 

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a Pilsner glass. When I smelled the mouth of the emptied bottle, all I could smell was skunk. Not sure if this bottle was on the store shelf too long or if every batch is this stinky. I swirled the glass a little and tried out my sniffer one more time. I could still smell skunk, but a hint of breadlines was there this time. This brew looked appealing--golden and fizzy. It took a few minutes for the white, one-inch head to recede to a thin white sheet of fine bubbles floating atop the brew. When the beer first hit my tongue, I was fooled into thinking Id have a refreshing, slightly sweet pale lager to enjoy. Brew had a slight bready sweetness on the tip of the tongue, but when it flowed through the rest of my mouth it tasted like I was licking the inside of a wet cardboard box. Mouthfeel was a tad richer than I expected after the initial fizziness of each sip dissipated. I would count the tiny bit of unexpected richness as a plus. Overall, I very much hated this brew and I would definitely never give it a second chance unless I knew the first one I drank was defective or old. I dont know how I can recommend a beer that smells like skunk and tastes like cardboard.

"Never turn your back on your beer."

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: Poured from a 12oz bottle into a stemless tulip glass (Brooklyn Brewery glass). Aroma is quite floral and a little fruity, but still smells crisp and a bit bready like a beer should. Deep golden hue is very inviting, but the head receded very quickly. Taste is earthy and floral right away at the front of the sip. The middle of the sip is where the fruitiness appears. The finish reveals a tiny bitter bite, but leaves you with a smooth, sweet aftertaste (aftertastes arent always bad!). For this style of beer, the mouthfeel is in that perfect, middle-of-the-road range. Not too light, but definitely not a heavy beer. Quite impressed with this beer. Its a very balanced brew and would accommodate a wide range of entrees if paired with a meal! (Too bad I already ate). "Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a chalice. Brew smells beautifully complex--grassy, mostly, with a hint of lemon and banana. The light, golden beer has the perfect level of haze, and the thin white head sat at the top of the brew throughout the entire drink. Taste is light, spicy, and a little tart. Very complex, yet refreshing. The tingle of the carbonation sits with you for a while, but it's not overwhelming. It seems to make the drink even more refreshing. I don't want to stop sipping! I'm so impressed with this beer. It's unexpectedly delicious--assertive flavors, without being over-the-top. Love it.

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a snifter. Smells boozy and woody with plenty of coffee aroma. Brew looks amazing--opaque black with a thin tan head. Taste is malty sweetness with a bit of alcohol bite on the front end. Then the coffee flavors hit you and sit for a while. That woody, nuttiness come around on the finish with a pleasant alcohol warming in the chest. This is a good brew to warm up with on a cold night. Palate is just perfect--full and rich with lower carbonation that gives the beer its delectable smoothness. Tasty tasty tasty. Another, please?

"Never turn your back on your beer."
beer_name: Terrapin Wake-n-Bake Coffee Oatmeal Imperial Stout

review_blob:
Poured from a 12oz bottle into a stein. Fresh hoppiness overwhelms the aroma, with a little bit of nuttiness present. Smells more like an IPA. Beer looks great! Color is a dark, rusty brown with a slight haze. Brew built up a pillowy 2-inch, light tan head when I poured it. The attack of the sip hit my tastebuds with a pleasantly assertive bitterness. But just as the beer continued to pour over the front of my tongue, it actually tasted quite metallic. A sweet nuttiness hit me at the middle of the sip, and continued through the finish. Beer has a very faint bitter and grassy aftertaste. Body of the beer is appropriately light for a session ale, but I felt it was over-carbonated, which distracted from the range of flavors this beer is showcasing. Overall, I was neither displeased nor dazzled by this beer. I like the contemporary fusion of brown and bitter, but Ive tasted better examples of this style.

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle bottle into a tulip glass. Brew smells odd. Not bad by any means, but odd. Very woodsy and earthy aroma--herbal, bitter, and sweet. Brew looks exactly like a good IPA should. deep copper color, with a soapy, lush, off-white head. Brews taste is consistent with its aromas. Citrusy and woody on the attack, a bit spicy and very floral in the middle, and a rush of bitterness on the finish. This IPA surprised me with how complex of an aroma it had. I was most impressed with how balanced the beer was while showing off a large range of flavors. This is a great brew!

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a Nonic glass. Brew smells funky, carmely, and sweet. The aromas definitely inform you this is going to be a malty beast. Beers warm, dark copper color is inviting, but it didnt render much of a head at all when I poured it into my glass. Only a thin layer of fine, off-white bubbles floated up to the surface, but they did remain there throughout the entire drink. Beer has a blast of flavor right on the attack of the sip. Some spiciness hits you on the tip of the tongue, then the rich malty flavors fill your mouth. The finish is where that unusual funkiness set in. Its a boozy finish as well, which has a nice chest-warming effect. Body of the brew is very, very rich. The fine carbonation provides the beer with its delightful smoothness. I very much enjoyed this brew. Im not yet well-versed in Scotch ales, but the funky characteristics (I dont mean this in a negative manner) in this brew caught me by surprise, which sets this Scotch ale apart from all the other ones Ive tasted previously. This is a yummy beer.

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. Brew smells funky, malty (naturally), and a tinge sour. Beer is opaque black in color with a small, but rich, tan head. Initial taste is sour and a little spicy. The thick malt lays in at the middle of the sip, and the finish is quite bitter. Mouthfeel has a little carbonation bite at the attack, but the rest is pure richness and creaminess. Overall, I dont dislike this beer. Its an interesting drink, but doesnt seem well balanced. The array of flavors work against each other rather than working in harmony.

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a Pilsner glass. Brew smells grassy, a little citrusy, with plenty of hop aroma present. Brew has a full, yellow color with just a little bit of haziness and rendered a white 1-inch head made up of fine bubbles--looks quite lush. Taste is grassy and citrusy at the beginning of the sip. The middle of the sip revealed that the brew has a pretty full malt profile and some floral notes! Then youre left with that perfect bitter and crisp finish. For a Pilsner, the body of the beer is quite ample, but still very refreshing. The mouthfeel has that nice bite of carbonation that doesnt stick with you too long so you can actually taste the beer. Ive tasted a few really good pilsners before, but this one tops my personal list. What a great brew!

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a Becker. Brew smells mild and fruity with a hint of corn. The pure golden hue and creamy white head look very inviting! Brew tastes fruity right from the beginning of the sip through the finish. Has subtle strawberry flavor. Actually tastes like eating a bowl of corn flakes for breakfast with strawberry slices on top. Body is lightly creamy and very drinkable. Overall this a refreshing and enjoyable brew. Would work well as a summer poolside drink. However the brew is quite simplistic in taste and didnt hold my attention for long.

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 33cl bottle into a chalice. Brew smells spicy foremost, some fruit aromas as well. This beer looks impeccable. Ive seen very few beers with such a vibrant yet natural and earthy hue. The lush off-white head stays at the top of the beer through the ENTIRE drink, and each time I tip my chalice, the foam smothers (not laces, smothers) the glass wall--amazing. Consistent with the aromas, I first taste the spices on the tip of my tongue. As the beer rushes through my mouth the creamy tingle dissipates a bit to reveal the beers subtle sweetness and floral notes. The finish is perfectly smooth and just a hint boozy. The mouthfeel of this beer is so delectably full and rich without being overwhelmingly heavy. The carbonation works so interestingly with an initial refreshing bite that turns into a smooth foam coating the tongue even after the finishing gulp. This is a fantastic beer and should be enjoyed by anyone who calls himself or herself a beer lover.

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a snifter. A - Smells floral, a little fruity, quite bitter, and just a hair boozy. A - Deep reddish brown hue. Fairly hazy with a small lightly tanned head. T - floral and fruity up front. Bit of caramel sweetness rushes in at the middle of the sip. More floral notes appear on the bitter finish. P - Medium bodied and lightly carbonated. Beer has very intense aromas and flavors. I feel the medium body and smoothness help balance those elements. O - Beer is so assertive in its flavors, but very well-balanced. Creates a great drinking experience. And the beer gets even tastier as it warms up!

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a snifter A - Smells woody and bitter. A little floral and funky as well. A - Has a similar look to Arrogant Bastard Ale. Reddish Brown, but a bit more murky. T - Taste is noticeably more bitter than Arrogant Bastard Ale. Definitely woody up front, then just a little bit of sweetness in the middle. The finish leaves you with a good amount of bitterness that sits in the mouth for a half minute or longer. Yummy P - Heavier body than ABA, but not too heavy. Still just as smooth. Not overly carbonated. O - An interesting variation of the Arrogant Bastard Ales. Ive not had the Oaked ABA before, but its contribution to this blend is what I found to be most notably different from the original ABA. The extra hoppiness was enjoyable at first, but got to be a little overwhelming after a little while. The high bitterness clashed with the extra oaky smoothness just a bit. Nonetheless, this was a very enjoyable and intense beer!

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a snifter. A - brew smells sweet, floral, and bourbony. Reminds me of the scent of a floral shop. Also some bitterness and booziness in the aromas. A - looks terrific. Dark Amber hue, a little murky. Thin, off white head. T - the bourbon flavors are obvious, but not so blatant that they obscure the original ABA flavor. I taste bourbon and woodiness on the attack, floral and slight carmely flavors in the middle. The finish builds up the bitterness on the back of the tongue, which then recedes and leaves you with a creamy, almost vanilla-like, flavor for the finale. Great range of flavors, although I feel the heavy bitterness almost clashes with the smooth, sweet bourbon aspects. P - Delightfully smooth, and not too heavy! The slight vanilla notes imparted from the bourbon aging give this ale a tinge of creaminess in the finish. O - Ive found a few bourbon aged beers that Ive thoroughly enjoyed, but Ive also tasted some shitty beers that use this type of aging as a gimmick to sell off their inferior product. This beer surprised me! It works quite well with the bourbon flavors, because ABA already has a nice caramel sweetness in its flavor profile. Again, I feel the bitterness of the hops clashes a little with the sweetness of the bourbon. But the floral flavors and aromatics of the hops work well with woody characteristics from the aging. An impressive entry to the ABA family!

"Never turn your back on your beer."

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a snifter. A - Woah! Big aromas in this beer. Smells very floral and boozy. Plenty of hop bitterness present as well A - Deep amber hue--just a tad darker than the standard ABA. The lightly tanned head receded down to a thin layer of bubbles that hung out atop the brew throughout the drink. T - The attack features an array of floral notes and plenty of malty sweetness which continues through the middle of the sip. The finish features that Stone signature blast of bitter which crescendos until it comes full circle and returns to the malty and caramely sweetness. Wow. P - Such a full and rich mouthfeel. I can feel my tongue counting up the calories. The bitter finish cuts right through the richness and gives it a nice balance. O - This is a BIG beer. Very full in maltiness and extremely bitter. But it, no doubt, creates an amazing drinking experience. This beer has such large range of flavors and aromas: malty, floral, bitter, and boozy. It is extraordinarily balanced for such an intense drink. Beers this bitter may not be for everyone, but i couldnt recommend it more. This is a supreme brew.

"Never turn your back on your beer."
